description: {"blocks":[{"key":"ch932","text":"The mammalian brain contains approximately 1,000 brain areas and each brain area contains multiple (up to 100) cell types. Neurons in one brain region can send projections to dozens of target regions, and distinct neuron types could project to different combinations of target regions. The enumeration and description of the brain’s cell types, and their brain-wide connectivity, is foundational for understanding how neural activity is routed across brain-wide neural circuits during normal behavior and how these processes are dysregulated in mental disorders.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8gmp0","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2ppo9","text":"Obtaining brain-wide single neuron reconstructions requires high-resolution, high-contrast imaging of entire brains – neuronal axons travel many centimeters (in the mouse) while individual axon collaterals could be finer than 100nm. Here, we present an integrated protocol for labeling and isotropic expansion of whole mouse brains that results in optically clear specimens ideally suited for high-resolution selective plane illumination microscopy (SPIM) imaging. Pipeline steps are modular, and the protocol is extensible to other large volume clearing and expansion applications.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9517d","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"crofb","text":"We have imaged expanded whole mouse brains generated using this protocol on our custom built ExA-SPIM microscope without need for any tissue slicing. These whole brain data sets are being used for tracing complete axonal morphology of individual neurons.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
